importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The start of the Paris Climate Agreement, marking a pivotal moment in global climate policy that shifted projected warming trajectories and associated heat extremes.
The baseline period for defining 'comparable days' (1991–2020), used to establish the reference for superhot days in the study.
The publication date of the study, signaling the current state of climate change attribution and public awareness of future heat risks.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The long-term projection of superhot days under current climate commitments, illustrating the future trajectory of climate-related heat extremes.
The period since the Paris Agreement, during which global emissions commitments have been implemented, showing measurable reductions in projected climate impacts.

keyTakeAways: The world is still facing a significant increase in dangerous 'superhot days' — 57 per year by 2100 — due to climate change, even under current commitments to the Paris Agreement.
Before the Paris Climate Agreement, a 4C warming scenario would have added 114 superhot days annually; today's 2.6C scenario adds only 57, reducing the worst-case impact by half.
Since 2015, the planet has already accumulated 11 additional superhot days on average.

Small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa will experience the largest increases in superhot days — with Panama projected at 149 extra days per year — despite contributing less than 1% of global carbon emissions.
The top carbon-polluting countries — the U.S., China, and India — are expected to face only 23–30 extra superhot days, despite being responsible for 42% of global CO2 emissions.
The stark disparity in heat exposure highlights climate injustice, with vulnerable nations bearing disproportionate climate burdens.
Experts warn that such inequalities may contribute to geopolitical instability and deepen global inequities between 'have' and 'have-not' nations.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A research organization that conducts climate attribution studies to determine how climate change contributes to extreme weather events.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This entity led the study on the attribution of superhot days to climate change, providing scientific credibility to the findings.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S.-based climate science research organization focused on climate data analysis and communication.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Climate Central is a key collaborator in the study, bringing expertise in climate data modeling and public outreach.

namedEntities.name: Paris Climate Agreement
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A global treaty adopted in 2015 to limit global warming to well below 2°C, with efforts to limit it to 1.5°C.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The agreement is central to the study's comparison of warming scenarios, showing how policy commitments have altered projected heat extremes.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He provides expert commentary on the continued severity of climate impacts despite reduced warming projections, emphasizing the danger of future outcomes.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A new climate study by World Weather Attribution and Climate Central finds that even under current global commitments to the Paris Climate Agreement, the Earth will still face 57 additional superhot days per year by 2100 — nearly two months of extreme heat. This represents a significant reduction from the 114 extra days predicted under a pre-Paris 4°C warming scenario, but still poses severe risks. The report emphasizes that climate change impacts are deeply unfair, with small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa facing massive increases in heat days — up to 149 per year — while major polluters such as the U.S., China, and India face only 23–30 extra days. Experts warn this inequality could exacerbate global tensions and deepen climate injustice, underscoring the urgent need for equitable climate action.
title: Climate study finds overheating world will add 57 superhot days a year
